mn43:1.1.comm: This sutta and the next are named for the class of scripture called vedalla, being the only suttas explicitly labelled as such. The root sense is to “split open” (vi-√dal) like a blossoming flower. These texts go beyond simple analysis or classification to “elaborate” the basic teachings (cf. the Sanskrit, which here has vaipulya, “expansion”). They share a similar method, where a series of questions and answers are carefully laid out, without revealing their purpose, but relentlessly driving towards the unraveling of the deepest meditation states emerging in Nibbana. While the Chinese parallels are broadly similar, there are many differences in detail, so they should be carefully studied before drawing any conclusions based on such “elaborations”.

mn43:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn43:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn43:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn43:1.3.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.
mn43:1.3.comm: Mahākoṭṭhita was one of the great disciples, and many of his conversations with Sāriputta are recorded. He was said to be foremost in the methods of textual analysis (AN 1.218:1.1), exemplified by such discussions as this. His verse is at Thag 1.2:0.4.

mn43:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn43:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Sāriputta:

mn43:2.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, duppaññoti vuccatī”ti?
mn43:2.2.eng: How is a witless person defined?”

mn43:2.3.pli: “‘Nappajānāti nappajānātī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā duppaññoti vuccati.
mn43:2.3.eng: “Reverend, they’re called witless because they don’t understand.

mn43:2.5.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhan’ti nappajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti nappajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti nappajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti nappajānāti.
mn43:2.5.eng: They don’t understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

mn43:2.6.pli: ‘Nappajānāti nappajānātī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā duppaññoti vuccatī”ti.
mn43:2.6.eng: They’re called witless because they don’t understand.”

mn43:2.7.pli: “Sādhāvuso”ti kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi:
mn43:2.7.eng: Saying “Good, reverend,” Mahākoṭṭhita approved and agreed with what Sāriputta said. Then he asked another question:

mn43:3.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, paññavāti vuccatī”ti?
mn43:3.2.eng: How is a wise person defined?”

mn43:3.3.pli: “‘Pajānāti pajānātī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā paññavāti vuccati.

mn43:3.5.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhan’ti pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti pajānāti.
mn43:3.5.eng: They understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

mn43:3.6.pli: ‘Pajānāti pajānātī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā paññavāti vuccatī”ti.
mn43:3.6.eng: They’re called wise because they understand.”

mn43:4.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, viññāṇanti vuccatī”ti?

mn43:4.3.pli: “‘Vijānāti vijānātī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā viññāṇanti vuccati.
mn43:4.3.comm: In defining a noun by its verb, Sāriputta clarifies that consciousness is not an entity but a function. Consciousness is simply the act of being conscious. Similar definitions are proposed for other fundamental Dhamma terms such as “feeling” and “perception”.

mn43:4.5.pli: Sukhantipi vijānāti, dukkhantipi vijānāti, adukkhamasukhantipi vijānāti.
mn43:4.5.comm: This definition is subtly different from that of “feeling” below (MN 43:7.5). The addition of the quotative particle -ti distances the verb for cognizing from the noun that is cognized. The Chinese and Tibetan parallels to this passage define consciousness here in the standard way as awareness of sense phenomena (MA 211 at T i 790c7, D 4094 mngon pa, nyu 81a7), which is more straightforward, but could be a result of normalization. Note too that the definition at SN 22.79:6.4 differs, where the context is universal experience in transmigration, rather than the development of meditation.

mn43:4.6.pli: ‘Vijānāti vijānātī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā viññāṇanti vuccatī”ti.
mn43:4.6.eng: It’s called consciousness because it cognizes.”

mn43:5.2.eng: are these things mixed or separate?

mn43:5.3.pli: Labbhā ca panimesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetun”ti?
mn43:5.3.eng: And can we completely disentangle them so as to describe the difference between them?”
mn43:5.3.comm: Vinibbhujati (“disentangle”) is used for the dissection of a corpse (Thig 16.1:24.1) or the unravelling of coiled banana sheaths (MN 35:22.3).

mn43:5.4.comm: “Wisdom” (paññā) and “consciousness” (viññāṇa) are two of the very many terms derived from the root ñā, “to know”. The prefixes act as intensifiers, but do not decisively distinguish the meaning, so while they are used consistently in doctrinal contexts, more loosely they can be interchangeable.

mn43:5.5.eng: these things are mixed, not separate.

mn43:5.6.pli: Na ca labbhā imesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetuṃ.
mn43:5.6.eng: And you can never completely disentangle them so as to describe the difference between them.

mn43:5.7.pli: Yaṃ hāvuso, pajānāti taṃ vijānāti, yaṃ vijānāti taṃ pajānāti.
mn43:5.7.eng: For you understand what you cognize, and you cognize what you understand.

mn43:5.8.pli: Tasmā ime dhammā saṃsaṭṭhā, no visaṃsaṭṭhā.
mn43:5.8.eng: That’s why these things are mixed, not separate.

mn43:5.9.pli: Na ca labbhā imesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetun”ti.
mn43:5.9.eng: And you can never completely disentangle them so as to describe the difference between them.”
mn43:5.9.comm: This dialogue cautions against pushing analysis too far.

mn43:6.2.pli: imesaṃ dhammānaṃ saṃsaṭṭhānaṃ no visaṃsaṭṭhānaṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇan”ti?
mn43:6.2.eng: what is the difference between these things that are mixed, not separate?”

mn43:6.4.pli: imesaṃ dhammānaṃ saṃsaṭṭhānaṃ no visaṃsaṭṭhānaṃ paññā bhāvetabbā, viññāṇaṃ pariññeyyaṃ.
mn43:6.4.eng: “The difference between these things is that wisdom should be developed, while consciousness should be completely understood.”
mn43:6.4.comm: This refers to the fundamental distinction made in the first discourse (SN 56.11): that which is to be developed (“wisdom”) pertains to the fourth noble truth, while that which is to be completely understood (“consciousness”) pertains to the first noble truth. Again, the distinction between them is functional rather than ontological.

mn43:7.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, vedanāti vuccatī”ti?

mn43:7.3.pli: “‘Vedeti vedetī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā vedanāti vuccati.

mn43:7.5.pli: Sukhampi vedeti, dukkhampi vedeti, adukkhamasukhampi vedeti.
mn43:7.5.eng: It feels pleasure, pain, and neutral.
mn43:7.5.comm: This definition is similar to that for consciousness, except without the distancing -ti. The feeling is the experience, whereas consciousnesses is that which is aware of the feeling. | The progress of the text is more subtle than it appears, as the question on feeling and consciousness starts to lay the groundwork for understanding the deep states of meditation that are discussed later.

mn43:7.6.pli: ‘Vedeti vedetī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā vedanāti vuccatī”ti.
mn43:7.6.eng: It’s called feeling because it feels.”

mn43:8.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, saññāti vuccatī”ti?

mn43:8.3.pli: “‘Sañjānāti sañjānātī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā saññāti vuccati.

mn43:8.5.pli: Nīlakampi sañjānāti, pītakampi sañjānāti, lohitakampi sañjānāti, odātampi sañjānāti.
mn43:8.5.eng: It perceives blue, yellow, red, and white.
mn43:8.5.comm: “Color” is a more sophisticated and less universal aspect of awareness than “feeling”, reflecting the fact that “perception” relates to higher-order functions like recognition and interpretation, which are involved in concept formation. The “perception” of lights and colors is often connected with the development of the four “form” jhānas (eg. MN 77:23.14), so we are paving the way for the apparently abrupt transition to the formless dimensions at MN 43:10.2 below.

mn43:8.6.pli: ‘Sañjānāti sañjānātī’ti kho, āvuso, tasmā saññāti vuccatī”ti.
mn43:8.6.eng: It’s called perception because it perceives.”

mn43:9.1.pli: “Yā cāvuso, vedanā yā ca saññā yañca viññāṇaṃ—

mn43:9.2.eng: are these things mixed or separate?

mn43:9.3.pli: Labbhā ca panimesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetun”ti?
mn43:9.3.eng: And can we completely disentangle them so as to describe the difference between them?”

mn43:9.4.pli: “Yā cāvuso, vedanā yā ca saññā yañca viññāṇaṃ—

mn43:9.5.eng: these things are mixed, not separate.

mn43:9.6.pli: Na ca labbhā imesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetuṃ.
mn43:9.6.eng: And you can never completely disentangle them so as to describe the difference between them.

mn43:9.7.pli: Yaṃ hāvuso, vedeti taṃ sañjānāti, yaṃ sañjānāti taṃ vijānāti.
mn43:9.7.eng: For you perceive what you feel, and you cognize what you perceive.

mn43:9.8.pli: Tasmā ime dhammā saṃsaṭṭhā no visaṃsaṭṭhā.
mn43:9.8.eng: That’s why these things are mixed, not separate.

mn43:9.9.pli: Na ca labbhā imesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetun”ti.
mn43:9.9.eng: And you can never completely disentangle them so as to describe the difference between them.”

mn43:10.1.pli: “Nissaṭṭhena hāvuso, pañcahi indriyehi parisuddhena manoviññāṇena kiṃ neyyan”ti?
mn43:10.1.eng: “What can be known by purified mind consciousness released from the five senses?”
mn43:10.1.comm: The key term “purified” (parisuddha) indicates the fourth absorption.

mn43:10.2.pli: “Nissaṭṭhena, āvuso, pañcahi indriyehi parisuddhena manoviññāṇena ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ neyyaṃ, ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ neyyaṃ, ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ neyyan”ti.
mn43:10.2.eng: “Aware that ‘space is infinite’ it can know the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’ it can know the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’ it can know the dimension of nothingness.”

mn43:11.1.eng: “How do you understand something that can be known?”

mn43:11.2.eng: “You understand something that can be known with the eye of wisdom.”
mn43:11.2.comm: In other words, through personal experience rather than scripture, tradition, etc.

mn43:12.2.eng: “The purpose of wisdom is direct knowledge, complete understanding, and giving up.”
mn43:12.2.comm: Wisdom is explained in functional terms through the effect that it produces.

mn43:13.1.eng: “How many conditions are there for the arising of right view?”

mn43:13.2.eng: “There are two conditions for the arising of right view:

mn43:13.3.pli: parato ca ghoso, yoniso ca manasikāro.
mn43:13.3.eng: the voice of another and rational application of mind.
mn43:13.3.comm: The “voice of another” is the teachings of the Dhamma, but these have to be actually investigated and applied internally.

mn43:13.4.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, dve paccayā sammādiṭṭhiyā uppādāyā”ti.
mn43:13.4.eng: These are the two conditions for the arising of right view.”

mn43:14.1.pli: “Katihi panāvuso, aṅgehi anuggahitā sammādiṭṭhi cetovimuttiphalā ca hoti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca hoti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā cā”ti?
mn43:14.1.eng: “When right view is supported by how many factors does it have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit?”
mn43:14.1.comm: That is, how does a stream-enterer practice further for arahantship?

mn43:14.2.pli: “Pañcahi kho, āvuso, aṅgehi anuggahitā sammādiṭṭhi cetovimuttiphalā ca hoti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca hoti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca.
mn43:14.2.eng: “When right view is supported by five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.

mn43:14.3.pli: Idhāvuso, sammādiṭṭhi sīlānuggahitā ca hoti, sutānuggahitā ca hoti, sākacchānuggahitā ca hoti, samathānuggahitā ca hoti, vipassanānuggahitā ca hoti.
mn43:14.3.eng: It’s when right view is supported by ethics, learning, discussion, serenity, and discernment.

mn43:14.4.pli: Imehi kho, āvuso, pañcahaṅgehi anuggahitā sammādiṭṭhi cetovimuttiphalā ca hoti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca hoti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā cā”ti.
mn43:14.4.eng: When right view is supported by these five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.”

mn43:15.1.eng: “How many states of existence are there?”

mn43:15.2.eng: “Reverend, there are these three states of existence.
mn43:15.2.comm: These three questions summarize dependent origination.

mn43:15.3.eng: Existence in the sensual realm, the realm of luminous form, and the formless realm.”

mn43:16.1.eng: “But how is there regeneration into a new state of existence in the future?”

mn43:16.2.eng: “It’s because of sentient beings—shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving—taking pleasure wherever they land.
mn43:16.2.comm: The term “shrouded by ignorance” (avijjānīvaraṇa) draws on the connection between nīvaraṇa, normally translated “hindrance”, and the cosmic serpent Vṛtra, the “constrictor” who wraps the world in darkness.

mn43:16.3.eng: That’s how there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.”

mn43:17.1.eng: “But how is there no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future?”

mn43:17.2.eng: “It’s when ignorance fades away, knowledge arises, and craving ceases.

mn43:17.3.eng: That’s how there is no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.”

mn43:18.1.eng: “But what, reverend, is the first absorption?”

mn43:18.2.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati—
mn43:18.2.eng: “Reverend, it’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn43:18.3.eng: This is called the first absorption.”

mn43:19.1.eng: “But how many factors does the first absorption have?”

mn43:19.3.pli: Idhāvuso, paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa bhikkhuno vitakko ca vattati, vicāro ca pīti ca sukhañca cittekaggatā ca.
mn43:19.3.eng: When a mendicant has entered the first absorption, placing the mind, keeping it connected, rapture, bliss, and unification of mind are present.
mn43:19.3.comm: These five absorption factors are found in the suttas here and, with other factors appended, at MN 111:4.1. The list summarizes the normal depiction of the first absorption, as the first four factors are all part of the standard first absorption formula, and all absorption or samādhi is characterized by unification of mind (eg. MN 20:3.3). They became a standard analysis of the first absorption in late canonical texts (eg. Ps 1.5:10.2, Ds 2.1.1:3.1, Vb 12:99.1, Pe 6:66.2).

mn43:19.4.pli: Paṭhamaṃ kho, āvuso, jhānaṃ evaṃ pañcaṅgikan”ti.
mn43:19.4.eng: That’s how the first absorption has five factors.”

mn43:20.1.eng: “But how many factors has the first absorption given up and how many does it possess?”

mn43:20.2.eng: “The first absorption has given up five factors and possesses five factors.

mn43:20.3.pli: Idhāvuso, paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa bhikkhuno kāmacchando pahīno hoti, byāpādo pahīno hoti, thinamiddhaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, vicikicchā pahīnā hoti;
mn43:20.3.eng: When a mendicant has entered the first absorption, sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt are given up.

mn43:20.4.pli: vitakko ca vattati, vicāro ca pīti ca sukhañca cittekaggatā ca.
mn43:20.4.eng: Placing the mind, keeping it connected, rapture, bliss, and unification of mind are present.
mn43:20.4.comm: All of these, except unification, are present to some degree before absorption, but now they manifest fully.

mn43:20.5.pli: Paṭhamaṃ kho, āvuso, jhānaṃ evaṃ pañcaṅgavippahīnaṃ pañcaṅgasamannāgatan”ti.
mn43:20.5.eng: That’s how the first absorption has given up five factors and possesses five factors.”

mn43:21.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, āvuso, indriyāni nānāvisayāni nānāgocarāni, na aññamaññassa gocaravisayaṃ paccanubhonti, seyyathidaṃ—
mn43:21.1.eng: “Reverend, these five faculties have different domains and different ranges, and don’t experience each others’ domain and range. That is,
mn43:21.1.comm: Again, apparently general questions are in fact laying the groundwork for a discussion on subtle states of meditation.

mn43:21.2.eng: the faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.

mn43:21.3.pli: Imesaṃ kho, āvuso, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ nānāvisayānaṃ nānāgocarānaṃ, na aññamaññassa gocaravisayaṃ paccanubhontānaṃ, kiṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ, ko ca nesaṃ gocaravisayaṃ paccanubhotī”ti?
mn43:21.3.eng: What do these five faculties, with their different domains and ranges, have recourse to? What experiences their domains and ranges?”

mn43:21.4.pli: “Pañcimāni, āvuso, indriyāni nānāvisayāni nānāgocarāni, na aññamaññassa gocaravisayaṃ paccanubhonti, seyyathidaṃ—

mn43:21.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, āvuso, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ nānāvisayānaṃ nānāgocarānaṃ, na aññamaññassa gocaravisayaṃ paccanubhontānaṃ, mano paṭisaraṇaṃ, mano ca nesaṃ gocaravisayaṃ paccanubhotī”ti.
mn43:21.6.eng: “These five faculties, with their different domains and ranges, have recourse to the mind. And the mind experiences their domains and ranges.”
mn43:21.6.comm: Each kind of sense experience is quite separate and distinct. The mind brings them all together and creates a sensible world in which a “self” can operate.

mn43:22.3.pli: Imāni kho, āvuso, pañcindriyāni kiṃ paṭicca tiṭṭhantī”ti?
mn43:22.3.eng: “These five faculties depend on what to continue?”

mn43:22.6.pli: Imāni kho, āvuso, pañcindriyāni āyuṃ paṭicca tiṭṭhantī”ti.
mn43:22.6.eng: “These five faculties depend on vitality to continue.”

mn43:22.7.eng: “But what does vitality depend on to continue?”

mn43:22.9.eng: “But what does warmth depend on to continue?”

mn43:22.11.pli: “Idāneva kho mayaṃ, āvuso, āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ evaṃ ājānāma:
mn43:22.11.eng: “Just now I understood you to say:

mn43:22.13.pli: Idāneva pana mayaṃ, āvuso, āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ evaṃ ājānāma:
mn43:22.13.eng: But I also understood you to say:

mn43:22.15.pli: Yathā kathaṃ panāvuso, imassa bhāsitassa attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
mn43:22.15.eng: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”

mn43:22.16.eng: “Well then, reverend, I shall give you a simile.

mn43:22.17.pli: upamāyapidhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
mn43:22.17.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

mn43:22.18.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, telappadīpassa jhāyato acciṃ paṭicca ābhā paññāyati, ābhaṃ paṭicca acci paññāyati;
mn43:22.18.eng: Suppose there was an oil lamp burning. The luminosity appears dependent on the flame, and the flame appears dependent on the luminosity.

mn43:22.19.pli: evameva kho, āvuso, āyu usmaṃ paṭicca tiṭṭhati, usmā āyuṃ paṭicca tiṭṭhatī”ti.
mn43:22.19.eng: In the same way, vitality depends on warmth to continue, and warmth depends on vitality to continue.”

mn43:23.1.pli: “Teva nu kho, āvuso, āyusaṅkhārā, te vedaniyā dhammā udāhu aññe āyusaṅkhārā aññe vedaniyā dhammā”ti?
mn43:23.1.eng: “Are the vital forces and the phenomena that are felt one and the same? Or are the vital forces one thing, and the phenomena that are felt another?”
mn43:23.1.comm: “Vital force” is āyusaṅkhāra. The suttas also use bhavasaṅkhāra (DN 16:3.10.5) and jīvitasaṅkhāra (DN 16:2.23.5) synonymously.

mn43:23.2.pli: “Na kho, āvuso, teva āyusaṅkhārā te vedaniyā dhammā.
mn43:23.2.eng: “The vital forces are not the same things as the phenomena that are felt.

mn43:23.3.pli: Te ca hāvuso, āyusaṅkhārā abhaviṃsu te vedaniyā dhammā, na yidaṃ saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa bhikkhuno vuṭṭhānaṃ paññāyetha.
mn43:23.3.eng: For if the vital forces and the phenomena that are felt were the same things, a mendicant who had attained the cessation of perception and feeling would not emerge from it.
mn43:23.3.comm: This introduces the most subtle of all meditation states, accessible only to non-returners and arahants who are fully accomplished in all the absorptions.

mn43:23.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, aññe āyusaṅkhārā aññe vedaniyā dhammā, tasmā saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa bhikkhuno vuṭṭhānaṃ paññāyatī”ti.
mn43:23.4.eng: But because the vital forces and the phenomena that are felt are different things, a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling can emerge from it.”

mn43:24.1.pli: “Yadā nu kho, āvuso, imaṃ kāyaṃ kati dhammā jahanti; athāyaṃ kāyo ujjhito avakkhitto seti, yathā kaṭṭhaṃ acetanan”ti?
mn43:24.1.eng: “How many things must this body lose before it lies abandoned, tossed aside like an insentient log?”

mn43:24.2.pli: “Yadā kho, āvuso, imaṃ kāyaṃ tayo dhammā jahanti—āyu usmā ca viññāṇaṃ; athāyaṃ kāyo ujjhito avakkhitto seti, yathā kaṭṭhaṃ acetanan”ti.
mn43:24.2.eng: “This body must lose three things before it lies abandoned, tossed aside like an insentient log: vitality, warmth, and consciousness.”
mn43:24.2.comm: This passage assumes the existence of a distinct vital force that is one of three factors required for life, which is why I have translated āyu here as “vitality” rather than “life”. Compare Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 8.7.2.11: “he who will live is conscious and warm, and he who will die is cold”.

mn43:25.1.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, āvuso, mato kālaṅkato, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno—imesaṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇan”ti?
mn43:25.1.eng: “What’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling?”
mn43:25.1.comm: This distinction is critical, as it sometimes happens that a person in deep meditation seems as if dead. Indeed, this confused even Ānanda at the Buddha’s deathbed (DN 16:6.8.1).

mn43:25.2.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, āvuso, mato kālaṅkato tassa kāyasaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, vacīsaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, cittasaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, āyu parikkhīṇo, usmā vūpasantā, indriyāni paribhinnāni.
mn43:25.2.eng: “When someone dies, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled; their vitality is spent; their warmth is dissipated; and their faculties have disintegrated.
mn43:25.2.comm: These processes are defined in the next sutta (MN 44:14.1).

mn43:25.3.pli: Yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno tassapi kāyasaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, vacīsaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, cittasaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, āyu na parikkhīṇo, usmā avūpasantā, indriyāni vippasannāni.
mn43:25.3.eng: When a mendicant has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled. But their vitality is not spent; their warmth is not dissipated; and their faculties are very clear.

mn43:25.4.pli: Yvāyaṃ, āvuso, mato kālaṅkato, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno—idaṃ nesaṃ nānākaraṇan”ti.
mn43:25.4.eng: That’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling.”

mn43:26.1.eng: “How many conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart?”

mn43:26.2.pli: “Cattāro kho, āvuso, paccayā adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā.
mn43:26.2.eng: “Four conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart.

mn43:26.3.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn43:26.3.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn43:26.4.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, cattāro paccayā adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā”ti.
mn43:26.4.eng: These four conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart.”

mn43:27.1.eng: “How many conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart?”

mn43:27.2.pli: “Dve kho, āvuso, paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā—
mn43:27.2.eng: “Two conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart:

mn43:27.3.pli: sabbanimittānañca amanasikāro, animittāya ca dhātuyā manasikāro.
mn43:27.3.eng: not focusing on any signs, and focusing on the signless.

mn43:27.4.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, dve paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā”ti.
mn43:27.4.eng: These two conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart.”

mn43:27.5.eng: “How many conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart?”

mn43:28.1.pli: “Tayo kho, āvuso, paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā ṭhitiyā—
mn43:28.1.eng: “Three conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart:

mn43:28.2.pli: sabbanimittānañca amanasikāro, animittāya ca dhātuyā manasikāro, pubbe ca abhisaṅkhāro.
mn43:28.2.eng: not focusing on any signs, focusing on the signless, and a previous determination.
mn43:28.2.comm: Before entering the meditation, one makes an inner resolve to remain there for a certain period of time.

mn43:28.3.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tayo paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā ṭhitiyā”ti.
mn43:28.3.eng: These three conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart.”

mn43:29.1.eng: “How many conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart?”

mn43:29.2.pli: “Dve kho, āvuso, paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā vuṭṭhānāya—
mn43:29.2.eng: “Two conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart:

mn43:29.3.pli: sabbanimittānañca manasikāro, animittāya ca dhātuyā amanasikāro.
mn43:29.3.eng: focusing on all signs, and not focusing on the signless.

mn43:29.4.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, dve paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā vuṭṭhānāyā”ti.
mn43:29.4.eng: These two conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart.”

mn43:29.5.pli: “Yā cāyaṃ, āvuso, appamāṇā cetovimutti, yā ca ākiñcaññā cetovimutti, yā ca suññatā cetovimutti, yā ca animittā cetovimutti—ime dhammā nānātthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti?
mn43:29.5.eng: “The limitless release of the heart, and the release of the heart through nothingness, and the release of the heart through emptiness, and the signless release of the heart: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”

mn43:30.1.pli: “Yā cāyaṃ, āvuso, appamāṇā cetovimutti, yā ca ākiñcaññā cetovimutti, yā ca suññatā cetovimutti, yā ca animittā cetovimutti—atthi kho, āvuso, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā nānātthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca;
mn43:30.1.eng: “There is a way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.

mn43:30.2.pli: atthi ca kho, āvuso, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā ekatthā, byañjanameva nānaṃ.
mn43:30.2.eng: But there’s also a way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.
mn43:30.2.comm: These terms can be used for distinct states of meditation as described below, but they can all be used of arahantship as well.

mn43:31.1.pli: Katamo cāvuso, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā nānātthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca?
mn43:31.1.eng: And what’s the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing?

mn43:31.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
mn43:31.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

mn43:31.3.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …

mn43:31.4.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

mn43:31.5.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
mn43:31.5.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

mn43:31.6.eng: This is called the limitless release of the heart.

mn43:32.1.eng: And what is the release of the heart through nothingness?

mn43:32.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn43:32.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

mn43:32.3.eng: This is called the heart’s release through nothingness.

mn43:33.1.eng: And what is the release of the heart through emptiness?

mn43:33.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
mn43:33.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

mn43:33.3.eng: ‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’

mn43:33.4.eng: This is called the release of the heart through emptiness.

mn43:34.1.eng: And what is the signless release of the heart?

mn43:34.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn43:34.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.

mn43:34.3.eng: This is called the signless release of the heart.

mn43:34.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā nānātthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
mn43:34.4.eng: This is the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.

mn43:35.1.pli: Katamo cāvuso, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānaṃ?
mn43:35.1.eng: And what’s the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?

mn43:35.2.pli: Rāgo kho, āvuso, pamāṇakaraṇo, doso pamāṇakaraṇo, moho pamāṇakaraṇo.
mn43:35.2.eng: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of limits.

mn43:35.3.pli: Te khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
mn43:35.3.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

mn43:35.4.pli: Yāvatā kho, āvuso, appamāṇā cetovimuttiyo, akuppā tāsaṃ cetovimutti aggamakkhāyati.
mn43:35.4.eng: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of limitless release of the heart.

mn43:35.5.pli: Sā kho panākuppā cetovimutti suññā rāgena, suññā dosena, suññā mohena.
mn43:35.5.eng: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

mn43:36.1.pli: Rāgo kho, āvuso, kiñcano, doso kiñcano, moho kiñcano.
mn43:36.1.eng: Greed is something, hate is something, and delusion is something.

mn43:36.2.pli: Te khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
mn43:36.2.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

mn43:36.3.pli: Yāvatā kho, āvuso, ākiñcaññā cetovimuttiyo, akuppā tāsaṃ cetovimutti aggamakkhāyati.
mn43:36.3.eng: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of release of the heart through nothingness.

mn43:36.4.pli: Sā kho panākuppā cetovimutti suññā rāgena, suññā dosena, suññā mohena.
mn43:36.4.eng: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

mn43:37.1.pli: Rāgo kho, āvuso, nimittakaraṇo, doso nimittakaraṇo, moho nimittakaraṇo.
mn43:37.1.eng: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of signs.

mn43:37.2.pli: Te khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
mn43:37.2.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

mn43:37.3.pli: Yāvatā kho, āvuso, animittā cetovimuttiyo, akuppā tāsaṃ cetovimutti aggamakkhāyati.
mn43:37.3.eng: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of signless release of the heart.

mn43:37.4.pli: Sā kho panākuppā cetovimutti suññā rāgena, suññā dosena, suññā mohena.
mn43:37.4.eng: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

mn43:37.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti.
mn43:37.5.eng: This is the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”

mn43:37.6.eng: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.

mn43:37.7.pli: Attamano āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn43:37.7.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita approved what Sāriputta said.
